God's neakes, now I remember me, I ha'
the rarest device in my head that ever breathed. Can you paint me a drivelling reeling song, and let the word be, uh.

sp.speaker: Payn.
sp.p: A belch.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: O, no no: uh, paint me uh, or nothing.

sp.speaker: Painter
sp.p: It can not be done sir, but by a seeming kind of drunkenness.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: No? well, let me have a good massy ring, with your own poesy graven in it, that must sing a small treble, word for word, thus; and if you will my true lover be,
Come follow me to the green wood.

sp.speaker: Painter
sp.l: O lord, sir, I can not make a picture sing.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.l: Why? 'zlid, I have seen painted things sing as sweet:
But I have't will tickle it, for a conceit i'faith.

div.stage: ¶ Enter Feliche, and Alberto.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: O dear Feliche, give me thy device.
How shall I purchase love of Rossaline?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: S'will, flatter her soundly.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Her love is such, I can not flatter her:
But with my utmost vehemence of speech,
I have adored her beauties.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Hast writ good moving unaffected rhymes to her.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: O, yes, Feliche, but she scorns my writ.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Hast thou presented her with sumptuous gifts?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Alas, my fortunes are too weak to offer them.

sp.speaker: Fell.
sp.l: O, than I have it, I'll tell thee what to do.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: What, good Feliche?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Go and hang thyself, I say, go hang thyself,
if that thou canst not give, go hang thyself:
I'll rhyme thee dead, or verse thee to the rope.
How thinkst thou of a poet that sung thus;
Munera sola pacant, sola addunt munera formam:
Munere solicits pallada, Cypris erit.
Munera, munera.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I'll go and breathe my woes unto the rocks,
And spend my grief upon the deafest seas.
I'll weep my passion to the senseless trees,
And load most solitary air with plaints.
For woods, trees, sea, or rocky Apennine,
Is not so ruthless as my Rossaline.
Farewell dear friend, expect no more of me,
Here ends my part, in this love's comedy.

div.stage: Exit Paynter.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Now master Balurdo, whether are you going, ha?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Signior Feliche, how do you faith, and by my troth, how do you?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Whether art thou going, bully?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: And as heaven help me, how do you?
How, do you i'faith he?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Whether art going man?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: O god, to the court, I'll be willing to give you grace and good countenance, if I may but see you in the presence.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: O to court? farewell.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: If you see one in a yellow taffeta doublet, cut upon carnation valour, a green hat, a blue pair of velvet hose, a gilt rapier, and an orange tawny pair of worsted silk stockings, that's I, that's I.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Very good, farewell.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Ho, you shall know me as easily, I ha' bought me a new green feather with a red sprig, you shall see my wrought shirt hang out at my breeches, you shall know me.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Very good, very good, farewell.

sp.speaker: Ball.
sp.p: Marry in the mask 'twill be somewhat hard. But if you hear anybody speak so wittily, that he makes all the room laugh; that's I, that's I. Farewell good signior.

div.stage: ¶ Enter Forobosco, Castilio, a boy carrying a gilt harp: Piero, Mellida in night apparel, Rossaline, Flavia, two pages.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Advance the music's prize, now capering wits,
Rise to your highest mount; let choice delight
Garland the brow of this triumphant night.
Sfoot, 'a sits like Lucifer himself.

sp.speaker: Rossa.
sp.p: Good sweet Duke, first let their voices, strain for music's price. Give me the golden harp: faith with your favour, I'll be umpiress.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.p: Sweet niece content: boys clear your voice and sing.

div.stage: 1. Cantat.

sp.speaker: Rossa.
sp.p: By this gold, I had rather have a servant with a short nose, and a thin hair, then have such a high stretched minikin voice.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Fair niece, your reason?

sp.speaker: Ross.
sp.p: By the sweet of love, I should fear extremely that he were an eunuch.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Spark spirit, how like you his voice?

sp.speaker: Ross.
sp.l: Spark spirit, how like you his voice?
sp.p: So help me, youth, thy voice squeaks like a dry cork shoe: come, come; let's hear the next.

div.stage: 2. Cantat.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Trust me, a good strong mean, well sung my boy.

div.stage: ¶ Enter Balurdo.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Hold, hold, hold: are ye blind, could you not see my voice coming for the harp. And I knock not division on the head, take hence the harp, make me a slip, and let me go but for nine pence. Sir mark, strike up for master Balurdo.

div.stage: 3. Cantat.
div.l: Judgement gentlemen, judgement. Wast not above line?
I appeal to your mouths that heard my song.
Do me right, and dub me knight Balurdo.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Kneel down, and I'll dub thee knight of the golden harp.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Indeed la, do, and I'll make you lady of the silver fiddlestick,

sp.speaker: Ross.
sp.p: Come, kneel, kneel.

div.stage: ¶ Enter a page to Balurdo,

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: My troth, I thank you, it hath never a whistle in't.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p:
Nay, good sweet coz raise up your drooping eyes,
and I were at the point of to have and to hold, from this day forward, I would be ashamed to look thus lumpish. What my pretty coz, 'tis but the loss of an odd maidenhead: shall's dance? thou art so sad, hark in mine ear. I was about to say, but I'll forbear.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: I come, I come, more than most honeysuckle sweet ladies, pine not for my presence, I'll return in pomp. Well spoken sir Jeffrey Balurdo. As I am a true knight, I feel honourable eloquence begin to grope me already.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Faith, mad niece, I wonder when thou wilt marry?

sp.speaker: Rossa.
sp.p: Faith, kind uncle, when men abandon jealousy, forsake taking of tobacco, and cease to wear their beards so rudely long. O, to have a husband with a mouth continually smoking, with a bush of furs on the ridge of his chin, ready still to slop into his foaming chaps; ah, 'tis more than most intolerable.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.p: Nay faith, sweet niece, I was mighty strong in thought we should have shut up night with an old comedy: the prince of Milan shall have Mellida, and thou shouldst have

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
nobody , good sweet uncle. I tell you, sir, I have 39. servants, and my monkey that makes the fortieth. Now I love all of them lightly for something, but affect none of them seriously for any thing. One's a passionate fool, and he flatters me above belief: the second's a tasty ape, and he rails at me beyond reason: the third's as grave as some censor, and he strokes up his moustaches three times, and makes six
plots of set faces, before he speaks one wise word: the fourth's as dry, as the burr of an artichoke; the fifth paints, and hath always a good colour for what he speaks: the sixth

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Stay, stay, sweet niece, what makes you thus suspect young gallants worth.

sp.speaker: Ross.
sp.p: O, when I see one were a periwig, I dread his hair; another wallow in a great slop, I mistrust the proportion of his thigh; and wears a ruffled boot, I fear the fashion of his leg. Thus, something in each thing, one trick in every thing makes me mistrust imperfection in all parts; and there's the full point of my addiction.

div.stage: The cornets sound a sennet.
¶ Enter Galeatzo, Matzagente, and Balurdo in maskery.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: The room's too scant: boys, stand in there, close.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: In faith, fair sir, I am too sad to dance.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: How's that, how's that? too sad? By heaven dance,
And grace him to, or, go to, I say no more.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: A burning glass, the word splendente Phoebo?
'Tis too curious, I conceit it not.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Faith, I'll tell thee. I'll no longer burn, than you'll shine and smile upon my love. For look ye fairest, by your pure sweets,
sp.l: I do not dote upon your excellence.
And faith, unless you shed your brightest beams
Of sunny favour, and acceptive grace
Upon my tender love, I do not burn:
sp.p:
Marry but shine, and I'll reflect your beams,
with fervent ardour. Faith I would be loath to flatter thee fair soul, because I love, not dote, court like thy husband; which thy father swears, to morrow morn I must be. This is all, and now from henceforth, trust me Mellida, I'll not speak one wise word to thee more.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.p: I trust ye.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: By my troth, I'll speak pure fool to thee now.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: You will speak the liker yourself.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Good faith, I'll accept of the coxcomb, so you will not refuse the babble.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Nay good sweet, keep them both, I am enamoured of neither.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Go to, I must take you down for this. Lend me your ear.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: A glow worm, the word? Splendescit tantum tenebris.

sp.speaker: Matz.
sp.p: O, lady, the glow worm figurates my valour: which shineth brightest in most dark, dismal and horrid achievements.

sp.speaker: Ross.
sp.p: Or rather, your glow worm represents your wit, which only seems to have fire in it, though indeed 'tis but an ignis fatuus, and shines only in the dark dead night of fool's admiration.

sp.speaker: Matz.
sp.p: Lady, my wit hath spurs, if it were disposed to ride you.

sp.speaker: Ross.
sp.p: Faith sir, your wits spurs have but walking rowels; dull, blunt, they will not draw blood: the gentlemen ushers may admit them the presence, for any wrong they can do to ladies.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p:
Truly, I have strained a note above Ela, for a device;
look you, 'tis a fair ruled singing book: the word, perfect, if it were pricked.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Though you are masked, I can guess who you are by your wit. You are not the exquisite Balurdo, the most rarely shaped Balurdo.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Who, I? No I am not sir Jeffrey Balurdo. I am not as well known by my wit, as an alehouse by a red lattice. I am not worthy to love and be beloved of Flavia.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: I will not scorn to favour such good parts, as are applauded in your rarest self.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Truly, you speak wisely, and like a gentlewoman of fourteen years of age. You know the stone called lapis; the nearer it comes to the fire, the hotter it is: and the bird, which the geometricians call auis, the farther it is from the earth, the nearer it is to the heaven: and love, the nigher it is to the flame, the more remote (There's a word, remote) the more remote it is from the frost, your wit is quick, a little thing pleaseth a young lady, and a small favour contenteth an old courtier; and so, sweet mistress I truss my codpiece point.

div.stage: ¶ Enter Feliche.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.p: What might import this flourish? bring us word.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Stand away: here's such a company of fly-boats, hulling about this galleass of greatness, that there's no boarding him.
Do you hear yond thing called, Duke?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: How now blunt Feliche, what's the news?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Yonder's a knight, hath brought Andrugio's head, and craves admittance to your chair of state.

div.stage: ¶ Cornets sound a sennet: enter Andrugio in armour.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Conduct him with attendance sumptuous,
Sound all the pleasing instruments of joy:
Make triumph, stand on tiptoe whilst we meet:
Oh sight most gracious, oh revenge most sweet!

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: We vow, by the honour of our birth, to recompense any man that bringeth Andrugio's head, with twenty thousand double pistolets, and the endearing to our choicest love.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: We still with most unmoved resolved confirm
Our large munificence: and here breathe
A sad and solemn protestation:
When I recall this vow, oh, let our house
Be even commanded, stained, and trampled on,
As worthless rubbish of nobility.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Then, here, Piero, is Andrugio's head,
Royally casked in a helm of steel:
Give me thy love, and take it. My dauntless soul
Hath that unbounded vigour in his spirits,
That it can bear more rank indignity,
With less impatience, than thy cankered hate
Can sting and venom his untainted worth,
With the most viperous sound of malice. Strike,
Oh, let no glimpse of honour light thy thoughts,
If there be any heat of royal breath
Creeping in thy veins, oh stifle it.
Be still thyself, bloody and treacherous.
Fame not thy house with an admired act
Of princely pity. Piero, I am come,
To soil thy house with an eternal blot
Of savage cruelty; strike, or bid me strike.
I pray my death; that thy ne'er dying shame
might live immortal to posterity.
Come, be a princely hangman, stop my breath.
O dread thou shame, no more than I dread death.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: We are amazed, our royal spirits numbed,
In stiff astonished wonder at thy prowess,
Most mighty, valiant, and high towering heart.
We blush, and turn our hate upon ourselves,
For hating such an unpeered excellence.
I joy my state: him whom I loathed before,
That now I honour, love; nay more, adore.
sp.stage: ¶ The still flutes sound a mournful sennet. Enter a cousin.
sp.l: But stay: what tragic spectacle appears,
Whose body bear you in that mournful hearse?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: The breathless trunk of young Antonio.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.p: Antonio (Ay me) my lord, my love, my

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Sweet precious issue of most honoured blood,
Rich hope, ripe virtue, oh untimely loss.
Come hither friend. Prithee do not weep:
Why, I am glad he's dead, he shall not see
His fathers vanquished, by his enemy.
Even in princely honour, nay prithee speak.
How died the wretched boy?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: My lord

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: I hope he died yet like my son, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Alas, my lord

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: He died unforced, I trust, and valiantly.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Poor gentleman, being

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Did his hand shake, or his eye look dull,
His thoughts reel, fearful when he struck the stroke?
And if they did, I'll rend them out the hearse,
Rip up his cerecloth, mangle his bleak face;
That when he comes to heaven, the powers divine
Shall ne'er take notice that he was my son.
I'll quite disclaim his birth: nay prithee speak:
And 'twere not hooped with steel, my breast would break.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: O that my spirit in a sigh could mount,
Into the sphere, where thy sweet soul doth rest.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: O that my tears, bedewing thy wan cheek,
Could make new spirit sprout in thy could blood.

sp.speaker: Bal ▪
sp.l: Verily, he looks as pitifully, as a poor John: as
I am true knight, I could weep like a stoned horse.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Villain, 'tis thou hast murdered my son.
Thy unrelenting spirit (Thou black dog,
That tookest no passion of his fatal love)
Hath forced him give his life untimely end.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: O that my life, her love, my dearest blood
Would but redeem one minute of his breath.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I seize that breath. Stand not amazed, great states:
I rise from death, that never lived till now.
Piero, keep thy vow, and I enjoy
More unexpressed height of happiness,
Than power of thought can reach: if not, lo here
There stands my tomb, and here a pleasing stage:
Most wished spectators of my tragedy,
To this end have I feigned, that her fair eye,
For whom I lived, might bless me ere I die.
Mell, can breath depaint my unconceived thoughts?
Can words describe my infinite delight,
Of seeing thee, my lord Antonio?
O no; conceit, breath, passion, words be dumb,
Whilst I instill the dew of my sweet bliss,
In the soft pressure of a melting kiss;
Sic, sic iwat ire sub umbras.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Fair son (Now I'll be proud to call thee son)
Enjoy me thus; my very breast is thine:
Possess me freely, I am wholly thine.

sp.speaker: Ant ▪
sp.p: Dear father ▪

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Sweet son, sweet son; I can speak no more:
My joy's passion flows above the shore,
And chokes the current of my speech.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Young Florence prince, to you my lips must beg,
For a remittance of your interest.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: In your fair daughter, with all my thought,
So help me faith, the naked truth I'll unfold;
He that was ne'er hot, will soon be cold.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: No man else makes claim unto her.

sp.speaker: Matz.
sp.l: The valiant speak truth in brief: no

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Truly, for sir Jeffrey Balurdo, he disclaims to have had any thing in her,

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Then here I give her to Antonio.
Royal, valiant, most respected prince,
Let's clip our hands; I'll thus observe my vow;
I promised twenty thousand double pistolets,
With the endearing to my dearest love,
To him that brought thy head; thine be the gold,
To solemnize our houses unity:
My love be thine, the all I have be thine.
Fill us fresh wine, the form we'll take by this:
We'll drink a health, while they two sip a kiss.
Now, there remains no discord that can sound
Harsh accents to the ear of our accord:
So please your niece to match.

sp.speaker: Ross.
sp.p: Troth uncle, when my sweet fac't coz hath told me how she likes the thing, called wedlock; may be I'll take a survey of the checkroll of my servants; and he that hath the best parts of, I'll prick him down for my husband.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: For passion of love now, remember me to my mistress, lady Rossaline, when she is pricking down the good parts of her servants. As I am true knight, I grow stiff: I shall carry it.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: I will.
Sound Lydian wires, once make a pleasing note,
On nectar streams of your sweet airs, to float.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Here ends the comic crosses of true love:
O may the passage most successful prove.

div.head: Epilogus.
div.p: Gentlemen, though I remain an armed epilogue, I stand not as a peremptory challenger of desert, either for him that composed the comedy, or for us that acted it: but a most submissive suppliant for both. What imperfection you have seen in us, leave with us, and we'll amend it; what hath pleased you, take with you, and cherish it. You shall not be more ready to embrace any thing commendable, than we will endeavour to amend all things reprovable. What we are, is by your favour. What we shall be, rests all in your applausive encouragements.
div.stage: Exit.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
